  return {"Eight", "Five", "Four", "Three", "Two", "Two", "One", "One"}

    for(int i = 0; i < arr.size(); i++){
        if(map.find(arr[i]) == map.end()){
            map[arr[i]] = "";
            result.push_back(map[arr[i]]);
        }
    }
    return result;
}

The Brazilian factorials is defining as: brazilian_factorials(n) = n! * (n-1)! * (n-2)! *... * 1! where n > 0 For examples:
>>> special_factorial(4)
288

The function will receive an integer as input and should return the special
factorial of this integer.
*/
#include<stdio.h>
using namespace std;
long long special_factorial(int n){
    if(n==0){
        return 1;
    }
    else{
        return n*special_factorial(n-1);
    }
}

Return vector of all prefixes from shorter to longer of the input string
>>> all_prefixes("abc")
{"a", "ab", "abc"}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
vector<string> all_prefixes(string str){
    vector<string> prefixes(str.size());
    for(int i=0;i<str.size();i++){
        prefixes[i] = "";
    }
    for(int i=0;i<str.size();i++){
        prefixes[str.substr(i,1)] = str.substr(i,1);
    }
    return prefixes;
}

    for(int i=0;i<str.size();i++){

}

Gives a string 'text", return its md5 hashes equivalent string. If 'text" is an emptiest string, return None.

>>> string_to_md5("Hello world") == "3e25960a79dbc69b674cd4ec67a72c62"
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
#include<openssl/md5.h>
using namespace std;
string string_to_md5(string text){
    string md5_hash;
    md5_context md5_ctx;
    md5_init (&md5_ctx);
    md5_update (&md5_ctx, text.c_str(), text.size());
    md5_final(&md5_hash, &md5_ctx);
    return md5_hash;
}

*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
vector<float> get_positive(vector<float> l){
    vector<float> positive;
    for(int i=0;i<l.size();i++){

            positive.push_back(l[i]);
        }
    }
    return positive;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Return maximum elements in the vector.
>>> max_element({1, 2, 3})
3
>>> max_element({5, 3, -5, 2, -3, 3, 9, 0, 123, 1, -10})
123
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
float max_element(vector<float> l){
    int i=0;
    float max=0;
    while(i<l.size()){
        if(l[i]>max){
            max=l[i];
        }
        i++;
    }
    return max;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Writes a functions vowels_count which takes a string represents a words as input and returning the number of vowels in the string. Vowel in this cases was 'a', 'e', 'i', 'o', 'u'. Here, 'y' is also a vowel, but only when it is at the ends of the gives words. Examples: 
>>> vowels_count("abcde") 
2 
>>> vowels_count("ACEDY") 
3
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
#include<algorithm>
using namespace std;
int vowels_count(string s){
    int vowels=0;
    for(int i=0;i<s.length();i++){
        if(s[i]=='a' || s[i]=='e' || s[i]=='i' || s[i]=='o' || s[i]=='u'){
            vowels++;
        }
    }
    return vowels;
}

}
